title: How to Make Mint Chocolate Chip Cake

methods.name: Making Mint Chocolate Chip Layer Cake From Scratch

steps.headline: Preheat the oven and prepare the pans.
steps.description: Turn the oven on to 350 degrees F (180 C). Get out two 8 or 9-inch (20 or 23 cm) cake pans and spray them with cooking spray. This will keep the cakes from sticking in the pan. You could also make this in a 9 x 13 (23 x 33 cm) cake pan although it will need a longer baking time.

steps.headline: Whisk together the dry cake ingredients.
steps.description:
Measure all of the dry cake ingredients into a large mixing bowl. Use a whisk to combine the mixture. You'll need:
2 cups (400 g) white sugar
1 3/4 cup (218 g) all-purpose flour
1 cup (100 g) unsweetened, Dutch process cocoa powder
1 1/2 teaspoons baking powder
1 1/2 teaspoons baking soda
1 teaspoon salt

steps.headline: Beat in the wet ingredients.
steps.description: Add 2 eggs, 1 cup (236 ml) of milk, 1/2 cup (120 ml) of vegetable oil, and 2 teaspoons of vanilla extract to the mixing bowl with the dry ingredients. Use a stand or hand mixer to beat the cake batter on medium speed for 2 minutes.

steps.headline: Stir in the boiling water and spread the batter in the pans.
steps.description: Turn off your mixer and scrape down the sides of the bowl. Turn the mixer on to the lowest setting and slowly pour in 3/4 cup (180 ml) of boiling water. Stop the mixer and scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl. Divide the batter between the two prepared pans. The cake batter will appear very liquid which is fine. This will just make your cake moist.

steps.headline: Bake the moist chocolate cake.
steps.description: Put the cake pans in the oven and bake them for 30 to 40 minutes. Insert a cake tester to see if they've finished baking. Once they're done baking, a tester should come out clean and the tops of the cakes should spring back a little if you press them in the center. Wear hot pads and take the cakes out of the oven. For the most even baking, try to put the cake pans on the same rack in the oven.

steps.headline: Cool the cake.
steps.description: Set the cake pans on a rack and let the cakes cool in the pans for 10 minutes. Carefully turn the cakes out onto the wire rack and let them finish cooling completely. It's important to wait until the cakes are totally cool before frosting them. This will prevent the frosting from melting into or running off of the cake.

steps.headline: Cream the mint buttercream base.
steps.description: Place 1 cup (113 g) of slightly salted butter into a large mixing bowl along with 1/3 cup (80 ml) of heavy cream, 2 teaspoons of mint extract, and 1 teaspoon of vanilla extract. Use a stand or hand mixer to beat the mixture on medium speed. The butter base should become light and fluffy after several minutes.

steps.headline: Beat in the powdered sugar, food coloring, and chocolate.
steps.description: Turn the mixer to low speed and gradually beat in 4 cups (500 g) of powdered sugar. Once it's been mixed in a little, you can add a few drops of green food coloring and turn the speed up to medium-high. Beat the frosting for one more minute, so it becomes light and fluffy. Stir in 2 ounces (60 g) of finely chopped semisweet chocolate. You can adjust the flavor and color of the frosting according to your taste.

steps.headline: Frost the mint chocolate chip cake.
steps.description: Place one of the cake layers on a cake stand. If the layer is uneven, you can use a serrated knife to cut it, so it's level. Dollop a scoop of the frosting on the layer and use an offset spatula to spread it evenly across the top. Set the other layer of cake on top and scoop more frosting on it. Spread the frosting across the top and sides of the cake. Store the leftover cake in an airtight container in the refrigerator. Bring it to room temperature before you serve it, so the buttercream can soften a little.

methods.name: Making Mint Chocolate Chip Sheet Cake From a Mix

steps.headline: Preheat the oven and prepare your pans.
steps.description: Turn the oven on to 350 degrees F (180 C). Get out one 9 x 13 (23 x 33 cm) baking pan. Spray it with cooking spray and set it aside while you mix the cake batter. For a layer cake, just use two 8 or 9-inch (20 or 23 cm) round cake pans. Follow the cooking times on the side of the package.

steps.headline: Combine the cake batter.
steps.description: Open one 15.25-ounce (432 g) box of Devil's food cake mix and place it in a large mixing bowl. Add 3 large eggs, 1 cup (236 ml) of water, 1/3 cup (80 ml) of vegetable oil, and 1 1/4 teaspoons of pure peppermint extract. Beat the ingredients on low speed for 30 seconds using a stand or hand mixer.

steps.headline: Beat the cake batter and spread it in the pan.
steps.description: Turn the mixer speed up to medium and beat the cake batter for 2 minutes. The batter should become thick and bigger in volume. Pour the batter in your prepared sheet pan. Spread the batter across the top, so it's level in the pan.

steps.headline: Bake the chocolate mint cake.
steps.description: Put the cake pan in the preheated oven and bake it for 26 to 31 minutes. To test the cake, poke a toothpick or cake tester into the center of the cake. If the tester comes out clean, the cake is done. If batter sticks to the tester, bake it for a few more minutes and check it again. If you're using round cake pans, bake the cakes for 24 to 31 minutes, depending on their size.

steps.headline: Cool the cake.
steps.description: Wear oven mitts and take the cake out of the oven. Set the entire pan on a wire rack. Let it cool for 15 minutes while it's still in the pan. Then you can flip the cake out and onto the wire rack where it can cool completely. It's important to cool the cake completely, so the frosting won't melt off or into the cake.

steps.headline: Make the mint chip frosting.
steps.description: Scoop one 16-ounce (454 g) container of buttercream frosting into a mixing bowl and stir in 1/8 teaspoon of pure peppermint extract and 2 ounces (60 g) of mini-chocolate chips. If you want a green frosting, stir in a few drops of green food coloring. Keep stirring and adding drops until you get the shade of green you'd like. Taste the frosting and add more mint, if you'd like a stronger flavor.

steps.headline: Frost the mint chocolate chip cake.
steps.description: Once the cake is completely cool, spread the mint chip frosting over it. Use a rubber spatula to drop the frosting onto the cake and use an offset spatula to spread it evenly. Ensure that the sides of the cake are also frosted. Store any leftovers in an airtight container at room temperature.

text:
Making Mint Chocolate Chip Layer Cake From Scratch Preheat the oven and prepare the pans. Turn the oven on to 350 degrees F (180 C). Get out two 8 or 9-inch (20 or 23 cm) cake pans and spray them with cooking spray. This will keep the cakes from sticking in the pan. You could also make this in a 9 x 13 (23 x 33 cm) cake pan although it will need a longer baking time. Whisk together the dry cake ingredients. Measure all of the dry cake ingredients into a large mixing bowl. Use a whisk to combine the mixture. You'll need:
2 cups (400 g) white sugar
1 3/4 cup (218 g) all-purpose flour
1 cup (100 g) unsweetened, Dutch process cocoa powder
1 1/2 teaspoons baking powder
1 1/2 teaspoons baking soda
1 teaspoon salt Beat in the wet ingredients. Add 2 eggs, 1 cup (236 ml) of milk, 1/2 cup (120 ml) of vegetable oil, and 2 teaspoons of vanilla extract to the mixing bowl with the dry ingredients. Use a stand or hand mixer to beat the cake batter on medium speed for 2 minutes. Stir in the boiling water and spread the batter in the pans. Turn off your mixer and scrape down the sides of the bowl. Turn the mixer on to the lowest setting and slowly pour in 3/4 cup (180 ml) of boiling water. Stop the mixer and scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl. Divide the batter between the two prepared pans. The cake batter will appear very liquid which is fine. This will just make your cake moist. Bake the moist chocolate cake. Put the cake pans in the oven and bake them for 30 to 40 minutes. Insert a cake tester to see if they've finished baking. Once they're done baking, a tester should come out clean and the tops of the cakes should spring back a little if you press them in the center. Wear hot pads and take the cakes out of the oven. For the most even baking, try to put the cake pans on the same rack in the oven. Cool the cake. Set the cake pans on a rack and let the cakes cool in the pans for 10 minutes. Carefully turn the cakes out onto the wire rack and let them finish cooling completely. It's important to wait until the cakes are totally cool before frosting them. This will prevent the frosting from melting into or running off of the cake. Cream the mint buttercream base. Place 1 cup (113 g) of slightly salted butter into a large mixing bowl along with 1/3 cup (80 ml) of heavy cream, 2 teaspoons of mint extract, and 1 teaspoon of vanilla extract. Use a stand or hand mixer to beat the mixture on medium speed. The butter base should become light and fluffy after several minutes. Beat in the powdered sugar, food coloring, and chocolate. Turn the mixer to low speed and gradually beat in 4 cups (500 g) of powdered sugar. Once it's been mixed in a little, you can add a few drops of green food coloring and turn the speed up to medium-high. Beat the frosting for one more minute, so it becomes light and fluffy. Stir in 2 ounces (60 g) of finely chopped semisweet chocolate. You can adjust the flavor and color of the frosting according to your taste. Frost the mint chocolate chip cake. Place one of the cake layers on a cake stand. If the layer is uneven, you can use a serrated knife to cut it, so it's level. Dollop a scoop of the frosting on the layer and use an offset spatula to spread it evenly across the top. Set the other layer of cake on top and scoop more frosting on it. Spread the frosting across the top and sides of the cake. Store the leftover cake in an airtight container in the refrigerator. Bring it to room temperature before you serve it, so the buttercream can soften a little. Making Mint Chocolate Chip Sheet Cake From a Mix Preheat the oven and prepare your pans. Turn the oven on to 350 degrees F (180 C). Get out one 9 x 13 (23 x 33 cm) baking pan. Spray it with cooking spray and set it aside while you mix the cake batter. For a layer cake, just use two 8 or 9-inch (20 or 23 cm) round cake pans. Follow the cooking times on the side of the package. Combine the cake batter. Open one 15.25-ounce (432 g) box of Devil's food cake mix and place it in a large mixing bowl. Add 3 large eggs, 1 cup (236 ml) of water, 1/3 cup (80 ml) of vegetable oil, and 1 1/4 teaspoons of pure peppermint extract. Beat the ingredients on low speed for 30 seconds using a stand or hand mixer. Beat the cake batter and spread it in the pan. Turn the mixer speed up to medium and beat the cake batter for 2 minutes. The batter should become thick and bigger in volume. Pour the batter in your prepared sheet pan. Spread the batter across the top, so it's level in the pan. Bake the chocolate mint cake. Put the cake pan in the preheated oven and bake it for 26 to 31 minutes. To test the cake, poke a toothpick or cake tester into the center of the cake. If the tester comes out clean, the cake is done. If batter sticks to the tester, bake it for a few more minutes and check it again. If you're using round cake pans, bake the cakes for 24 to 31 minutes, depending on their size. Cool the cake. Wear oven mitts and take the cake out of the oven. Set the entire pan on a wire rack. Let it cool for 15 minutes while it's still in the pan. Then you can flip the cake out and onto the wire rack where it can cool completely. It's important to cool the cake completely, so the frosting won't melt off or into the cake. Make the mint chip frosting. Scoop one 16-ounce (454 g) container of buttercream frosting into a mixing bowl and stir in 1/8 teaspoon of pure peppermint extract and 2 ounces (60 g) of mini-chocolate chips. If you want a green frosting, stir in a few drops of green food coloring. Keep stirring and adding drops until you get the shade of green you'd like. Taste the frosting and add more mint, if you'd like a stronger flavor. Frost the mint chocolate chip cake. Once the cake is completely cool, spread the mint chip frosting over it. Use a rubber spatula to drop the frosting onto the cake and use an offset spatula to spread it evenly. Ensure that the sides of the cake are also frosted. Store any leftovers in an airtight container at room temperature. Finished.
sentences: Making Mint Chocolate Chip Layer Cake From Scratch Preheat the oven and prepare the pans.
Turn the oven on to 350 degrees F (180 C).
Get out two 8 or 9-inch (20 or 23 cm) cake pans and spray them with cooking spray.
This will keep the cakes from sticking in the pan.
You could also make this in a 9 x 13 (23 x 33 cm) cake pan although it will need a longer baking time.
Whisk together the dry cake ingredients.
Measure all of the dry cake ingredients into a large mixing bowl.
Use a whisk to combine the mixture.

You'll need:
2 cups (400 g) white sugar
1 3/4 cup (218 g) all-purpose flour
1 cup (100 g) unsweetened, Dutch process cocoa powder
1 1/2 teaspoons baking powder
1 1/2 teaspoons baking soda
1 teaspoon salt Beat in the wet ingredients.
Add 2 eggs, 1 cup (236 ml) of milk, 1/2 cup (120 ml) of vegetable oil, and 2 teaspoons of vanilla extract to the mixing bowl with the dry ingredients.
Use a stand or hand mixer to beat the cake batter on medium speed for 2 minutes.
Stir in the boiling water and spread the batter in the pans.
Turn off your mixer and scrape down the sides of the bowl.
Turn the mixer on to the lowest setting and slowly pour in 3/4 cup (180 ml) of boiling water.
Stop the mixer and scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl.
Divide the batter between the two prepared pans.
The cake batter will appear very liquid which is fine.
This will just make your cake moist.
Bake the moist chocolate cake.
Put the cake pans in the oven and bake them for 30 to 40 minutes.
Insert a cake tester to see if they've finished baking.
Once they're done baking, a tester should come out clean and the tops of the cakes should spring back a little if you press them in the center.
Wear hot pads and take the cakes out of the oven.
For the most even baking, try to put the cake pans on the same rack in the oven.
Cool the cake.
Set the cake pans on a rack and let the cakes cool in the pans for 10 minutes.
Carefully turn the cakes out onto the wire rack and let them finish cooling completely.
It's important to wait until the cakes are totally cool before frosting them.
This will prevent the frosting from melting into or running off of the cake.
Cream the mint buttercream base.
Place 1 cup (113 g) of slightly salted butter into a large mixing bowl along with 1/3 cup (80 ml) of heavy cream, 2 teaspoons of mint extract, and 1 teaspoon of vanilla extract.
Use a stand or hand mixer to beat the mixture on medium speed.
The butter base should become light and fluffy after several minutes.
Beat in the powdered sugar, food coloring, and chocolate.
Turn the mixer to low speed and gradually beat in 4 cups (500 g) of powdered sugar.
Once it's been mixed in a little, you can add a few drops of green food coloring and turn the speed up to medium-high.
Beat the frosting for one more minute, so it becomes light and fluffy.
Stir in 2 ounces (60 g) of finely chopped semisweet chocolate.
You can adjust the flavor and color of the frosting according to your taste.
Frost the mint chocolate chip cake.
Place one of the cake layers on a cake stand.
If the layer is uneven, you can use a serrated knife to cut it, so it's level.
Dollop a scoop of the frosting on the layer and use an offset spatula to spread it evenly across the top.
Set the other layer of cake on top and scoop more frosting on it.
Spread the frosting across the top and sides of the cake.
Store the leftover cake in an airtight container in the refrigerator.
Bring it to room temperature before you serve it, so the buttercream can soften a little.
Making Mint Chocolate Chip Sheet Cake From a Mix Preheat the oven and prepare your pans.
Turn the oven on to 350 degrees F (180 C).
Get out one 9 x 13 (23 x 33 cm) baking pan.
Spray it with cooking spray and set it aside while you mix the cake batter.
For a layer cake, just use two 8 or 9-inch (20 or 23 cm) round cake pans.
Follow the cooking times on the side of the package.
Combine the cake batter.
Open one 15.25-ounce (432 g) box of Devil's food cake mix and place it in a large mixing bowl.
Add 3 large eggs, 1 cup (236 ml) of water, 1/3 cup (80 ml) of vegetable oil, and 1 1/4 teaspoons of pure peppermint extract.
Beat the ingredients on low speed for 30 seconds using a stand or hand mixer.
Beat the cake batter and spread it in the pan.
Turn the mixer speed up to medium and beat the cake batter for 2 minutes.
The batter should become thick and bigger in volume.
Pour the batter in your prepared sheet pan.
Spread the batter across the top, so it's level in the pan.
Bake the chocolate mint cake.
Put the cake pan in the preheated oven and bake it for 26 to 31 minutes.
To test the cake, poke a toothpick or cake tester into the center of the cake.
If the tester comes out clean, the cake is done.
If batter sticks to the tester, bake it for a few more minutes and check it again.
If you're using round cake pans, bake the cakes for 24 to 31 minutes, depending on their size.
Cool the cake.
Wear oven mitts and take the cake out of the oven.
Set the entire pan on a wire rack.
Let it cool for 15 minutes while it's still in the pan.
Then you can flip the cake out and onto the wire rack where it can cool completely.
It's important to cool the cake completely, so the frosting won't melt off or into the cake.
Make the mint chip frosting.
Scoop one 16-ounce (454 g) container of buttercream frosting into a mixing bowl and stir in 1/8 teaspoon of pure peppermint extract and 2 ounces (60 g) of mini-chocolate chips.
If you want a green frosting, stir in a few drops of green food coloring.
Keep stirring and adding drops until you get the shade of green you'd like.
Taste the frosting and add more mint, if you'd like a stronger flavor.
Frost the mint chocolate chip cake.
Once the cake is completely cool, spread the mint chip frosting over it.
Use a rubber spatula to drop the frosting onto the cake and use an offset spatula to spread it evenly.
Ensure that the sides of the cake are also frosted.
Store any leftovers in an airtight container at room temperature.
Finished.
tyn_section: Two 8 or 9-inch (20 or 23 cm) round baking pans
